answers.content_html: Interference is a superposition of two waves to form a resultant wave with higher or lower frequency.
answers.feedback_html: With the superposition of two waves, the frequency of the resultant wave does not change.

answers.content_html: Interference is a superposition of two waves to form a wave of larger or smaller amplitude.
answers.feedback_html: Interference results in a wave with longer or shorter amplitude.

answers.content_html: Interference is a superposition of two waves to form a resultant wave with higher or lower velocity.
answers.feedback_html: The superposition of two waves does not cause a change in velocity.

answers.content_html: Interference is a superposition of two waves to form a resultant wave with longer or shorter wavelength.
answers.feedback_html: Interference occurs between two waves with nearly equal wavelengths and the resultant wave will also have the same wavelength.

answers.content_html: The reflection of a wave is the change in amplitude of a wave when it bounces off a barrier.
answers.feedback_html: Reflection does not always change the amplitude of a wave.

answers.content_html: The reflection of a wave is the change in frequency of a wave when it bounces off a barrier.
answers.feedback_html: Reflection does not change the frequency of a wave.

answers.content_html: The reflection of a wave is the change in velocity of a wave when it bounces off a barrier.
answers.feedback_html: The velocity of a wave remains same after reflection.

answers.content_html: The reflection of a wave is the change in direction of a wave when it bounces off a barrier.
answers.feedback_html: This is correct because after reflection, the direction of the wave changes.

stem_html: What is the reflection of a wave?

answers.content_html: True
answers.feedback_html: The amplitudes of waves add up whether or not the waves are propagating in the same line.

answers.content_html: False
answers.feedback_html: The amplitudes of the waves also add up when they are not propagating in same line.

stem_html: Is this statement true or false? The amplitudes of waves add up only if they are propagating in the same line.

answers.content_html: The frequency depends on the propagation speed and the density of the string.
answers.feedback_html: The frequency of standing waves does not depend on the density of string.

answers.content_html: The frequency depends on the propagation speed and the length of the string.
answers.feedback_html: The frequency depends up the propagation speed because the length of string is fixed.

answers.content_html: The frequency depends on the density and the length of the string.
answers.feedback_html: The frequency depends on the length but not the density of the string.

answers.content_html: The frequency depends on the propagation speed, the density, and the length of the string.
answers.feedback_html: The frequency depends on the length and the speed but is independent of the density of the string.

stem_html: In standing waves on a string, what does the frequency depend on?

answers.content_html: \frac{X}{2}
answers.feedback_html: The amplitude will not get halved after pure constructive interference of waves.

answers.content_html: X
answers.feedback_html: The amplitude will not remain same after pure constructive interference of waves.

answers.content_html: 2X
answers.feedback_html: In pure constructive interference of waves, the amplitude of the resultant wave will be the sum of the amplitudes of the individual waves.

answers.content_html: X^{2}
answers.feedback_html: The amplitude of the resultant wave cannot be obtained by multiplying the amplitudes of the individual waves.

stem_html: Two identical waves with an amplitude X superimpose in a way that pure constructive interference occurs. What is the amplitude of the resultant wave?

answers.content_html: Conductivity
answers.feedback_html: Conductivity is an ability of a material to conduct electric current and it is not a cause of refraction.

answers.content_html: Opacity
answers.feedback_html: Opacity only tells about the amount of light passing through a medium, so a change in opacity cannot assure refraction.

answers.content_html: Ductility
answers.feedback_html: Ductility is the property of a body by which it can be cast into the shape of wires; hence, it is not related to refraction of light.

answers.content_html: Density
answers.feedback_html: A change in density of a material is the main cause of refraction of light.

stem_html: Which property of a medium causes refraction?

answers.content_html: True
answers.feedback_html: Spherical waves can superimpose to give interference patterns.

answers.content_html: False
answers.feedback_html: Spherical waves can superimpose to give a resultant wave with a different amplitude.

stem_html: Is this statement true or false? Spherical waves can superimpose.

answers.content_html: due to superposition with the reflected waves from the ends of the string
answers.feedback_html: Waves reflected from the ends of the string are inverted; hence, they superimpose to give a standing wave.

answers.content_html: due to superposition with the reflected waves from the walls of the room
answers.feedback_html: Waves reflected from walls are not perfectly inverted and cannot form standing waves on superposition.

answers.content_html: due to superposition with waves generated from the body of the guitar
answers.feedback_html: Waves reflected from the guitar are not perfectly inverted and cannot form standing waves on superposition.

stem_html: Why does a standing wave form on a guitar string?

answers.content_html: Because the pressure of water at the two ends of the pool is same
answers.feedback_html: The constant pressure is not responsible for refraction of light.

answers.content_html: Because the pressures of water at the two ends of the pool are different
answers.feedback_html: The difference in pressure is not responsible for refraction of light.

answers.content_html: Because the density of water at the two ends of the pool is same
answers.feedback_html: Refraction does not occur at the interface of two media with same density

answers.content_html: Because the density of water at the two ends of the pool is different
answers.feedback_html: The variation of density causes refraction of light.

stem_html: Why do water waves traveling from the deep end to the shallow end of a swimming pool experience refraction?

answers.content_html: The crests and the troughs of waves traveling in the same direction combine to form a criss-cross pattern.
answers.feedback_html: Waves traveling in same direction will not form a criss-cross pattern.

answers.content_html: The crests and the troughs of waves traveling in different directions combine to form a criss-cross pattern.
answers.feedback_html: A criss-cross pattern will be formed when waves traveling in different directions superimposeresulting from constructive and destructive interference .

stem_html: Why do water waves sometimes appear like a complex criss-cross pattern?

answers.content_html: Destructive interference results in waves with greater amplitudes being formed in places farther away from the epicenter.
answers.feedback_html: Destructive interference cannot result in a wave with a greater amplitude.

answers.content_html: Constructive interference results in waves with greater amplitudes being formed in places farther away from the epicenter.
answers.feedback_html: Constructive interference results in waves with greater amplitudes; hence, it causes more damage farther away from the epicenter.

answers.content_html: The standing waves of great amplitudes are formed in places farther away from the epicenter.
answers.feedback_html: Standing waves generally do not form in earthquakes.

answers.content_html: The pulse waves of great amplitude are formed in places farther away from the epicenter.
answers.feedback_html: Pulse waves are not generated during earthquakes.

stem_html: Occasionally, during earthquakes, areas near the epicenter are not damaged while those farther away are damaged. Why could this occur?
